Title: Linking forum posts - warhol-03-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
In today's world where erotic images are seen almost daily (whether or not you want to see them) it's quite difficult to imagine the furore caused by many of the images created by Warhol. The late 50s to early 60s was an era of great social change, much of which was concerned with sexuality and censorship. Art, theatre, films and literature were all rigorously monitored for perceived sexual content (in case it corrupted the masses) - a classic example is the 'Lady Chatterly's Lover' case: http://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/oct/22/dh-lawrence-lady-chatterley-trial As stated in the lecture, much of Warhol's 'pornography' featured the tease - the implied possibility rather than the act - so that the 'pornographic' context lies more with the viewer and how they interpret what's going on, rather than in actual representation of specific sexual behaviour. As such, it's difficult to class his work as pornography per se. How much of the outrage about his work was due to the shots of male genitalia? Would there have been the same outcry if it had only featured women?
Upvotes:
7
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Excellent points, Judith. I've changed the title of your post, in case it causes offence. You're absolutely right to highlight that it's really important to situate Warhol's work in the context of the 1960s, when the testing of many boundaries relating to sexuality and sex occurred. The comparison with Lawrence's book is great! It opens up another key question: how might images, rather than text, cause offence? What do we mean by 'obscenity'?
Instructor's post : Excellent points, Judith. I've changed the title of your post, in case it causes offence. Title: Linking forum posts - warhol-03-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
I think it's interesting how many of the themes, subjects, and general creativity may be related back to Andy Warhol's homosexuality and his openness about it. Perhaps viewing the world as an 'outsider' provided a very distinct viewpoint. Being different and open about it (also his dress, appearance) takes away inhibitions - removes the risk because he's already an outsider. It's not just how he reconciled his sexuality to religion, but how he reconciled his sexuality to life, America, culture, publicity.... As someone has mentioned: 'I don't see why his sexuality should matter'. Perhaps, in America in the 1960's - it really does matter. Was the art influence by his sexuality, and/or was his open living influenced by his art?
Upvotes:
2
Great point! I think his open living was influenced by his art.
Upvotes:
0
I think his sexuality is refleccted in his art. In his art but also in his appearence, as you said. Sexuality is something about yourself, is part of you. Without it, you may see things different. That is why I think that yes, what we see in his works is his identity.
Upvotes:
0
As a lifelong follower of Andy Warhol, I am slightly ashamed to admit that I had forgotten the very homoerotic nature of Warhol's initial forays and failures into the world of 'fine art' throughout the 1950s. The following is a touching and at times chilling profile of Andy Warhol that relies upon source material rather that conjecture and speculation... http://youtu.be/UQXpqQO4vaE
Upvotes:
0
One can easily speculate Warhol's once overt homoerotic content became ubiquitous and subvert as and after he attained the recognition and notoriety he claimed to desire.
Upvotes:
0
Andy Warhol is very important for the queer culture. Considering his first films about the homoerotic content, we can say his one of the first film makers at this kind at his era. His homosexuality is liquid to all his work, point of view, full of symbolism and allegory. In this way, I believe that his homosexuality was something like an idea for him.
Upvotes:

The next best thing to do is to ask yourself why you are offended? As a queer man, I find the word delightfully less constrictive than either 'gay' or 'homosexual.' The truth is that human sexuality is a continuum without boundaries. Queer culture acknowledges this fluidity.

I always thought of Warhol as presenting an asexuality. I assumed that it was probably a pose and/or a way of keeping people guessing to increase the mystery and thereby the 'superstardom'.

The first works that Warhol submitted to a fine art gallery, homoerotic drawings of male nudes, were rejected for being too openly gay.The fact that Warhol's homosexuality influenced his work and shaped his relationship to the art world is a major subject of scholarship on the artist and is an issue that Warhol himself addressed in interviews, in conversation with his contemporaries, and in his publications.Throughout his career, Warhol produced erotic photography and drawings of male nudes. Many of his most famous works

Don't forget the relationship between warhol's openly gay works and art market. The second one loves provocation and that always increases prices. Thats something we must have in mind with warhol, an artist that loved money, and he openly admitted! The openly gay works of warhol is another product of success of his 'factory'
Upvotes:
0
I wonder how different his art would've been if he had taken a different path in his personal life and allowed himself to be openly gay? Perhaps the art would've come back to the same juncture of pop art because in the end he cared most about money and therefore needed to find a way to make art that allowed for that. However, it is interesting to speculate.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
There's a really interesting point here to raise about language and labelling, I think. Warhol produced some of his most famous work before the gay rights movement kicked off in the late 1960s. (The Stonewall riots occurred in 1969.) During the 50s and 60s, when he was working in New York, the word 'queer' (used, for the most part, pejoratively) would have been in wide circulation. One of the many things that can be taken from Warhol's POPism is the different terms that are used by Warhol to refer to his own sexuality, and that of some of the others at the Factory: swish, homosexual, fag. There are certainly accounts of Warhol's private life in which we can clearly identify him as gay - that is, having emotional and sexual relationships with other men. (The most explicit of these, if probably the most factually unreliable, if John Giorno's extraordinary You've Got To Burn To Shine .) In recent years, Warhol has been 'claimed' by queer theory, which retrospectively reads him and his work as challenging concrete definitions of gender and sexuality. Jennifer, the term 'queer' is problematic for a lot of people - gay and straight. But what is useful to think through is the different ways in which the word has been mobilised in different historical periods, and how it can be politically useful.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
There's a really interesting point here to raise about language and labelling, I think. Warhol produced some of his most famous work before the gay rights movement kicked off in the late 1960s. (The Stonewall riots occurred in 1969.) During the 50s and 60s, when he was working in New York, the word 'queer' (used, for the most part, pejoratively) would have been in wide circulation. One of the many things that can be taken from Warhol's POPism is the different terms that are used by Warhol to refer to his own sexuality, and that of some of the others at the Factory: swish, homosexual, fag. There are certainly accounts of Warhol's private life in which we can clearly identify him as gay - that is, having emotional and sexual relationships with other men. (The most explicit of these, if probably the most factually unreliable, if John Giorno's extraordinary You've Got To Burn To Shine .) In recent years, Warhol has been 'claimed' by queer theory, which retrospectively reads him and his work as challenging concrete definitions of gender and sexuality. Jennifer, the term 'queer' is problematic for a lot of people - gay and straight. But what is useful to think through is the different ways in which the word has been mobilised in different historical periods, and how it can be politically useful.

Title: Linking forum posts - warhol-03-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
I think it's interesting how many of the themes, subjects, and general creativity may be related back to Andy Warhol's homosexuality and his openness about it. Perhaps viewing the world as an 'outsider' provided a very distinct viewpoint. Being different and open about it (also his dress, appearance) takes away inhibitions - removes the risk because he's already an outsider. It's not just how he reconciled his sexuality to religion, but how he reconciled his sexuality to life, America, culture, publicity.... As someone has mentioned: 'I don't see why his sexuality should matter'. Perhaps, in America in the 1960's - it really does matter. Was the art influence by his sexuality, and/or was his open living influenced by his art?
Upvotes:
2
Great point! I think his open living was influenced by his art.
Upvotes:
0
I think his sexuality is refleccted in his art. In his art but also in his appearence, as you said. Sexuality is something about yourself, is part of you. Without it, you may see things different. That is why I think that yes, what we see in his works is his identity.

0

Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Warhol: celibacy homosexuality and the church.
Input.posts:
An interesting article: http://www.patheos.com/blogs/badcatholic/2012/10/andy-warhol-gay-and-catholic.html In the piece it states 'For Andy Warhol to be openly gay (he mentions he’d “always had a lot of fun with that — just watching the expression on people’s faces…) and at the same time intentionally celibate seems to represent a certain peace about the man, an intellectual separation of the sinless same-sex attraction and the sinful homosexual action, and an effort at communion with the teachings of the Catholic Church.' I thought this was very interesting, and gave a little insight into how Warhol might have reconciled his feelings for men while remaining devout in a religion that is not always known for it's acceptance of homosexuals.
Upvotes:
1
I find it very fascinating that he was so openly gay during a time when it was not at all accepted as is it today. Besides being a great artist, he was a strong man to be able to stand up and admit he was homosexual during a time when society did not recognize it. I wonder what he would think now about our society and homosexuality after 20 plus years after he died.
Upvotes:
2
I think he was a very lonely soul despite being around many. He always seem sad.
Upvotes:
4
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
That's a really great point, Bunny - thanks for raising it. Warhol lived through a fascinating period in American history, from when homosexuality was illegal, through the start of the gay rights movement, and - in the 1980s - the gay population was hit by HIV/AIDS. His published diaries feature quite a bit of commentary on his fears about HIV/AIDS. But I do wonder whether 'openness' is the right word. POPism, in which he talks about being gay, wasn't published until 1980. Before that, how did his homosexuality manifest in his persona and his artwork?
Instructor's post : That's a really great point, Bunny - thanks for raising it. Input.threadtitle: The Philosophy of Andy Warhol (From A to B and Back Again)
Input.posts:
See Extract One in Week Two. I believe this tracks a simple arithmetic logic, but uses a discussion of sex to do so. It is about working a series of a, b logic statements but seeing if it can be made more meaningful to the reader by using attitudes to sex, and then men and women as the a and b variables.
Upvotes:
1
That book (great title!) is amazing and warholian in the sense that is all very contradictory: logical in its illogical premises, shallow and, because of that, full of deep insights, playful and serious. And it works. I think pop is that: when Nik Cohn talked about pop music he said that sanity and sense killed it. Could this be also applied to pop art?
Upvotes:
0
With regard to The [so called] Philosophy of Andy Warhol... In March 1974 Andy Warhol signed two book contracts with Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. One contract was for what would become The Philosophy of Andy Warhol (From A to B and Back Again) and the other for a book that Andy planned to do on PAULETTE GODDARD's life. Warhol agreed to give BOB COLACELLO half of the $35,000 advance to 'get him going' on the proposal and outline. The books were to be titled The and Her ('and if and when Andy did an autobiography, that would be called Me', according to Colacello). (BC207) The Paulette Goddard book never materialised (she wasn't very forthcoming with Hollywood gossip) and Pat Hackett ended up writing much of the Philosophy book. Bob Colacello gave her half of his advance. According to Colacello, Andy 'absolutely refused to consider' giving Hackett a percentage of the book's future income and also 'gave her a curt turnoff' when she asked for a credit - a byline - on the book. (BC208) Pat Hackett: 'On the first book, The Philosophy of Andy Warhol (From A to B and Back Again), I did eight separate interviews with Andy on the basis of which I wrote chapters 1 through 8 and chapter 10. Then, using material from conversations Andy had taped between himself and Bob Colacello and Brigid Berlin, I wrote the introductory chapter and chapters 9, 11, 12, 13 and 14. It was the first major project Andy and I had worked on together, and after the book was published, in 1975, he asked to co-author the second book with him - his memoirs of the sixties, which we decided to call Popism.' (AWDXV) Bob Colacello: 'I hadn't fully comprehended what I'd gotten myself into by ghostwriting the [Philosophy] book, until Andy was photographed for the cover of New York magazine, which had bought the first serial rights. They posed him in a closet, sitting at a typewriter, under a headline that read: 'Andy Warhol's Greatest Secret: He Likes to Write.' It finally hit me then - I was part of a big lie, and while it had lined my pockets, it robbed my ego of any hope of recognition. Pat Hackett probably felt even more ripped off: Nine chapters were wholly hers; four were mostly mine; one, 'The Tingle,' was Brigid's, and all three of us had worked on the prologue.' (BC309) From... http://www.warholstars.org/chron/philosophy.html
Upvotes:
3
There was a recent panel discussion on YouTube between Bob Colacello, Brigid Berlin, and Vincent Fremont on Andy Warhol during which they shared, among other stories, anecdotes about how Bob Colacello would get stoned and 'channel' the voice and philosophy of Andy Warhol while Brigid Berlin took dictation and helped keep Colacello in character. Bob Colacello was Andy Warhol's social collaborator, photographer, and travel companion, as well as editor of Warhol's Interview magazine for twelve years between 1970 and 1982. Brigid Berlin was one of Andy Warhol's 'Superstars' and appeared in numerous Warhol films including 'Chelsea Girls' in 1966 and 'Ciao! Manhattan' in 1972 before working full time as a transcriptionist at Interview magazine from 1975 to beyond Warhol's death in 1987. Vincent Fremont has been working for Warhol since 1969 and was a central contributor to Warhol's film, television, and video forays before serving as vice president of Andy Warhol Enterprises and as one of the named founding members of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts as laid out in Warhol's last will & testament. Until the dissolution in October 2011 of the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board to which he also consulted, Vincent Fremont held a lucrative position as the sole sales agent for artworks in the possession of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts. http://m.youtube.com/watch?v=i17g3wPDfa4
Upvotes:
1
Denis, thank you for these. I'm loving so many of the forum contributions and references. You've given us a wealth of info and a springboard in just these two comments alone. I'm happily wasting hours perusing the warholstars.org site. It appears AW was comfortable appropriating more than images. He wasn't generous about giving others credit. So much for collaboration, I guess. What a complicated guy. As an aside, it hit me hard to learn that Jed Johnson(Jay's twin) died on TWA flight 800's crash on July 17, 1996 as my best friend also died in that crash. It was a NYC to Paris flight that crashed off Long Island. She was a homicide detective with the Portland(Oregon) Police Department. 45 years old. So sad.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
One of the useful things to think through in relation to 'The Philosophy of Andy Warhol' is whether it reads as a manifesto of some kind. Various artists and artistic movements have written manifestoes - here is one by Claes Oldenburg, for instance. Warhol's book is divided into sections on 'Big Themes': Love, Fame, Work, Time, Art, etc. How are we to understand this book - does it straddle the line between autobiography and manifesto?

Input.posts:
See Extract One in Week Two. I believe this tracks a simple arithmetic logic, but uses a discussion of sex to do so. It is about working a series of a, b logic statements but seeing if it can be made more meaningful to the reader by using attitudes to sex, and then men and women as the a and b variables.

1
That book (great title!) is amazing and warholian in the sense that is all very contradictory: logical in its illogical premises, shallow and, because of that, full of deep insights, playful and serious. And it works. I think pop is that: when Nik Cohn talked about pop music he said that sanity and sense killed it. Could this be also applied to pop art?
Upvotes:
0
With regard to The [so called] Philosophy of Andy Warhol... In March 1974 Andy Warhol signed two book contracts with Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. One contract was for what would become The Philosophy of Andy Warhol (From A to B and Back Again) and the other for a book that Andy planned to do on PAULETTE GODDARD's life. Warhol agreed to give BOB COLACELLO half of the $35,000 advance to 'get him going' on the proposal and outline. The books were to be titled The and Her ('and if and when Andy did an autobiography, that would be called Me', according to Colacello). (BC207) The Paulette Goddard book never materialised (she wasn't very forthcoming with Hollywood gossip) and Pat Hackett ended up writing much of the Philosophy book. Bob Colacello gave her half of his advance. According to Colacello, Andy 'absolutely refused to consider' giving Hackett a percentage of the book's future income and also 'gave her a curt turnoff' when she asked for a credit - a byline - on the book. (BC208) Pat Hackett: 'On the first book, The Philosophy of Andy Warhol (From A to B and Back Again), I did eight separate interviews with Andy on the basis of which I wrote chapters 1 through 8 and chapter 10. Then, using material from conversations Andy had taped between himself and Bob Colacello and Brigid Berlin, I wrote the introductory chapter and chapters 9, 11, 12, 13 and 14. It was the first major project Andy and I had worked on together, and after the book was published, in 1975, he asked to co-author the second book with him - his memoirs of the sixties, which we decided to call Popism.' (AWDXV) Bob Colacello: 'I hadn't fully comprehended what I'd gotten myself into by ghostwriting the [Philosophy] book, until Andy was photographed for the cover of New York magazine, which had bought the first serial rights. They posed him in a closet, sitting at a typewriter, under a headline that read: 'Andy Warhol's Greatest Secret: He Likes to Write.' It finally hit me then - I was part of a big lie, and while it had lined my pockets, it robbed my ego of any hope of recognition. Pat Hackett probably felt even more ripped off: Nine chapters were wholly hers; four were mostly mine; one, 'The Tingle,' was Brigid's, and all three of us had worked on the prologue.' (BC309) From... http://www.warholstars.org/chron/philosophy.html
Upvotes:
3
There was a recent panel discussion on YouTube between Bob Colacello, Brigid Berlin, and Vincent Fremont on Andy Warhol during which they shared, among other stories, anecdotes about how Bob Colacello would get stoned and 'channel' the voice and philosophy of Andy Warhol while Brigid Berlin took dictation and helped keep Colacello in character. Bob Colacello was Andy Warhol's social collaborator, photographer, and travel companion, as well as editor of Warhol's Interview magazine for twelve years between 1970 and 1982. Brigid Berlin was one of Andy Warhol's 'Superstars' and appeared in numerous Warhol films including 'Chelsea Girls' in 1966 and 'Ciao! Manhattan' in 1972 before working full time as a transcriptionist at Interview magazine from 1975 to beyond Warhol's death in 1987. Vincent Fremont has been working for Warhol since 1969 and was a central contributor to Warhol's film, television, and video forays before serving as vice president of Andy Warhol Enterprises and as one of the named founding members of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts as laid out in Warhol's last will & testament. Until the dissolution in October 2011 of the Andy Warhol Art Authentication Board to which he also consulted, Vincent Fremont held a lucrative position as the sole sales agent for artworks in the possession of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts. http://m.youtube.com/watch?v=i17g3wPDfa4
Upvotes:
1
Denis, thank you for these. I'm loving so many of the forum contributions and references. You've given us a wealth of info and a springboard in just these two comments alone. I'm happily wasting hours perusing the warholstars.org site. It appears AW was comfortable appropriating more than images. He wasn't generous about giving others credit. So much for collaboration, I guess. What a complicated guy. As an aside, it hit me hard to learn that Jed Johnson(Jay's twin) died on TWA flight 800's crash on July 17, 1996 as my best friend also died in that crash. It was a NYC to Paris flight that crashed off Long Island. She was a homicide detective with the Portland(Oregon) Police Department. 45 years old. So sad.

0

I'm happily wasting hours perusing the warholstars.org site. It appears AW was comfortable appropriating more than images. He wasn't generous about giving others credit. So much for collaboration, I guess. What a complicated guy. As an aside, it hit me hard to learn that Jed Johnson(Jay's twin) died on TWA flight 800's crash on July 17, 1996 as my best friend also died in that crash. It was a NYC to Paris flight that crashed off Long Island. She was a homicide detective with the Portland(Oregon) Police Department. 45 years old. So sad.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
One of the useful things to think through in relation to 'The Philosophy of Andy Warhol' is whether it reads as a manifesto of some kind. Various artists and artistic movements have written manifestoes - here is one by Claes Oldenburg, for instance. Warhol's book is divided into sections on 'Big Themes': Love, Fame, Work, Time, Art, etc. How are we to understand this book - does it straddle the line between autobiography and manifesto?

Input.threadtitle: Attempt to Murder Warhol : Altamont :: Heyday of The Factory : Woodstock
Input.posts:
As the idealism of the 'Summer of Love' (1967) had its culmination at Woodstock (August 1969) and ended with the murder at Altamont (December 1969), so Andy's vision of an artistic utopia, The Factory, was permanently altered by the attempt on his life by an associate (June 1968). In both cases, a certain naivete about the possibility of collective cooperation was permanently lost. Andy's near-death experience made him, once again, a mirror of his culture, but this time in a most unwelcome way.
Upvotes:
0
Yes, and Andy took it further by making an artwork of a gun like the one that nearly killed him. I don't think many victims of violence would create an artwork based on their personal experience. The gun silkscreen must have been startling to contemporary society, and it certainly made a statement about the commodity and icon status of the gun at that time.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Has anyone read the SCUM Manifesto by Valeria Solanas? (It's widely available online...) 'Having stripped the world of conversation, friendship and love, the male offers us these paltry substitutes: `Great Art' and `Culture' : The male `artist' attempts to solve his dilemma of not being able to live, of not being female, by constructing a highly artificial world in which the male is heroized, that is, displays female traits, and the female is reduced to highly limited, insipid subordinate roles, that is, to being male. The male `artistic' aim being, not to communicate (having nothing inside him he has nothing to say), but to disguise his animalism, he resorts to symbolism and obscurity (`deep' stuff). The vast majority of people, particularly the `educated' ones, lacking faith in their own judgment, humble, respectful of authority (`Daddy knows best'), are easily conned into believing that obscurity, evasiveness, incomprehensibility, indirectness, ambiguity and boredom are marks of depth and brilliance. `Great Art' proves that men are superior to women, that men are women, being labeled `Great Art', almost all of which, as the anti-feminists are fond of reminding us, was created by men. We know that `Great Art' is great because male authorities have told us so, and we can't claim otherwise, as only those with exquisite sensitivities far superior to ours can perceive and appreciated the slop they appreciated.' Although her perspective is pretty extreme at times, the core arguments of this passage are correlative to feminist art history's argument that there could be no 'great women artist' because art and culture was aligned to the masculine and did not view their work as truly artistic. How do you feel about Solanas - can we think about her shooting Warhol in a positive way, for feminism perhaps, or was it an isolated act of aggression?

Has anyone read the SCUM Manifesto by Valeria Solanas? (It's widely available online...) 'Having stripped the world of conversation, friendship and love, the male offers us these paltry substitutes: `Great Art' and `Culture' : The male `artist' attempts to solve his dilemma of not being able to live, of not being female, by constructing a highly artificial world in which the male is heroized, that is, displays female traits, and the female is reduced to highly limited, insipid subordinate roles, that is, to being male. The male `artistic' aim being, not to communicate (having nothing inside him he has nothing to say), but to disguise his animalism, he resorts to symbolism and obscurity (`deep' stuff). The vast majority of people, particularly the `educated' ones, lacking faith in their own judgment, humble, respectful of authority (`Daddy knows best'), are easily conned into believing that obscurity, evasiveness, incomprehensibility, indirectness, ambiguity and boredom are marks of depth and brilliance. `Great Art' proves that men are superior to women, that men are women, being labeled `Great Art', almost all of which, as the anti-feminists are fond of reminding us, was created by men. We know that `Great Art' is great because male authorities have told us so, and we can't claim otherwise, as only those with exquisite sensitivities far superior to ours can perceive and appreciated the slop they appreciated.' Although her perspective is pretty extreme at times, the core arguments of this passage are correlative to feminist art history's argument that there could be no 'great women artist' because art and culture was aligned to the masculine and did not view their work as truly artistic. How do you feel about Solanas - can we think about her shooting Warhol in a positive way, for feminism perhaps, or was it an isolated act of aggression?

Input.threadtitle: Attempt to Murder Warhol : Altamont :: Heyday of The Factory : Woodstock
Input.posts:
As the idealism of the 'Summer of Love' (1967) had its culmination at Woodstock (August 1969) and ended with the murder at Altamont (December 1969), so Andy's vision of an artistic utopia, The Factory, was permanently altered by the attempt on his life by an associate (June 1968). In both cases, a certain naivete about the possibility of collective cooperation was permanently lost. Andy's near-death experience made him, once again, a mirror of his culture, but this time in a most unwelcome way.
Upvotes:
0
Yes, and Andy took it further by making an artwork of a gun like the one that nearly killed him. I don't think many victims of violence would create an artwork based on their personal experience. The gun silkscreen must have been startling to contemporary society, and it certainly made a statement about the commodity and icon status of the gun at that time.

1

Title: Linking forum posts - warhol-03-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
Hello Class, I wanted to briefly mention Warhol's ' Race Riot 1964 ,' perhaps his most political piece in the ' Death and Disaster Series .' The 60s were an incredibly tumultuous time in the United States; death was literally everywhere -- assassinations of MLK, JFK, Medgar Evers, & RFK & the Vietnam War. And the Civil Rights movement was impossible to miss. This piece of Warhol's really spoke to me as I find it one of his more powerful artworks. I am not at all well versed in Andy Warhol's politics or art so I wanted to ask the question to the class and professors if Warhol frequently tackled themes of race in his works or was this piece just a one of kind work? Is there much scholarship/analysis on this piece? Thanks! Best, Courtney Young
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Thanks for this post, Courtney! A book that you might find useful is Thomas Crow's 'The Rise of the Sixties: American and European Art in the Era of Dissent', which does mention Warhol's 'Race Riot'. Most usefully, Crow identifies the '50s and '60s as a particularly turbulent era which many artists of the time drew from, or were inspired by. In relation to race and ethnicity, you might be interested in a series of works made by Warhol in 1980, called 'Ten Portraits of Jews of the 20th Century'. There's an interesting piece on the controversy this series generated here .

Warhol´s view in this is very interesting .In some ways his conception showed that the division between 'commercial ' and 'high' art was prefabricated .
Upvotes:
0
Throughout history artists have relied on patronage and commissions for their income, and tailored their works to suit the men with the money. To me, that is commercial art. Many 'old masters' and world-famous works can be seen as advertisements - the ceiling of the Sistine chapel as an ad for the Catholic Church, portraits of people advertising their wealth and power, and all those battle scenes portraying the status of nations as international players in the territorial and trade wars, most of which were grounded in global economics.
Upvotes:
3
That's true Judith, but wouldn't you say what art was then and what art is now are very different things? During the Renaissance the art that they made all served a purpose - it was commissioned with a function, generally a religious function, sometimes votive, commemorative, or to uphold status or establishment. And rather than creative geniuses, artists were artisans, generally paid less than the carpenters who built the structures they painted on. And artisans came under a different categorisation to businessmen or merchants, who belonged to a far superior social level. Today it feels like there are a range of artists to fit many social strata. There are commercial artists for advertising or illustrating or making faux abstract paintings to be mass produced for IKEA or some other store. There are artists who still belong to the 20th century notion of the romantic creative genius struggling with notions of identity and the human condition (which has such an enduring appeal that it is worth revisiting), there are artists who use concept to explore contemporary social challenges in response to globalisation, technology and regenerate thinking, and there are artists who are businessmen, who appear to have consciously and often successfully engaged with market forces. What is challenging is that often these artforms overlap, and also they can all be commoditised. Many artists start out defying and challenging the status quo, including the art establishment itself. The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it. And it is irresistible - think Emin, Banksy etc. It turns their art into commodity which is irresistible to the artist, and irresistible to the buyer - they can be a part of or associated with something that is both powerful and edgy. The idea of making art purely for money is challenging the status quo - challenging our perceptions of the intrinsic value of art - of course it's going to work! Hirst has gone all out - he not only overtly makes art as a commodity - his art boasts that that is what he is doing and he uses (and abuses) artistic motifs that often carry emotional associations for society, thus intrinsically undermines the very artistic values he is purporting to uphold.

Warhol had the quality of a naïf who was ahead of his time when it came to money and art. He was transparent in his desire for money for his art. They could become rich instead.

Interesting, because for me it was the opposite way: I went to art school so when I interned at a prestigious NYC gallery, I was coming from an academic background in which I admired artworks based on their aesthetic and intellectual value. About Warhol and business, there was a segment in Burns's Andy Warhol Documentary explaining that Warhol became more 'businesslike' after recovering from the shooting (so early 70s). One of the first moves was to sell off the existing inventory, which had naturally appreciated in value by the early 70s, then undertook commissions for portraits, plus made films for the commercial market (e.g., Warhol's Dracula (1974), which was actually made by Paul Morrissey). Warhol's crew also shifted, out went the drag queens and hustlers, in came those who could work in a more businesslike way (like Morrissey). During this time, Warhol also began Interview Magazine, which of course helped solidify his place among the 'celebs' -- but also the well-known and interesting people. One could also be a tad skeptical and say that the magazine and such increased the value of the Warhol brand .

Throughout history artists have relied on patronage and commissions for their income, and tailored their works to suit the men with the money. To me, that is commercial art. Many 'old masters' and world-famous works can be seen as advertisements - the ceiling of the Sistine chapel as an ad for the Catholic Church, portraits of people advertising their wealth and power, and all those battle scenes portraying the status of nations as international players in the territorial and trade wars, most of which were grounded in global economics.
Upvotes:
3
That's true Judith, but wouldn't you say what art was then and what art is now are very different things? During the Renaissance the art that they made all served a purpose - it was commissioned with a function, generally a religious function, sometimes votive, commemorative, or to uphold status or establishment. And rather than creative geniuses, artists were artisans, generally paid less than the carpenters who built the structures they painted on. And artisans came under a different categorisation to businessmen or merchants, who belonged to a far superior social level. Today it feels like there are a range of artists to fit many social strata. There are commercial artists for advertising or illustrating or making faux abstract paintings to be mass produced for IKEA or some other store. There are artists who still belong to the 20th century notion of the romantic creative genius struggling with notions of identity and the human condition (which has such an enduring appeal that it is worth revisiting), there are artists who use concept to explore contemporary social challenges in response to globalisation, technology and regenerate thinking, and there are artists who are businessmen, who appear to have consciously and often successfully engaged with market forces. What is challenging is that often these artforms overlap, and also they can all be commoditised. Many artists start out defying and challenging the status quo, including the art establishment itself. The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it. And it is irresistible - think Emin, Banksy etc. It turns their art into commodity which is irresistible to the artist, and irresistible to the buyer - they can be a part of or associated with something that is both powerful and edgy. The idea of making art purely for money is challenging the status quo - challenging our perceptions of the intrinsic value of art - of course it's going to work! Hirst has gone all out - he not only overtly makes art as a commodity - his art boasts that that is what he is doing and he uses (and abuses) artistic motifs that often carry emotional associations for society, thus intrinsically undermines the very artistic values he is purporting to uphold.

About Warhol and business, there was a segment in Burns's Andy Warhol Documentary explaining that Warhol became more 'businesslike' after recovering from the shooting (so early 70s). One of the first moves was to sell off the existing inventory, which had naturally appreciated in value by the early 70s, then undertook commissions for portraits, plus made films for the commercial market (e.g., Warhol's Dracula (1974), which was actually made by Paul Morrissey). Warhol's crew also shifted, out went the drag queens and hustlers, in came those who could work in a more businesslike way (like Morrissey). During this time, Warhol also began Interview Magazine, which of course helped solidify his place among the 'celebs' -- but also the well-known and interesting people. One could also be a tad skeptical and say that the magazine and such increased the value of the Warhol brand .

Throughout history artists have relied on patronage and commissions for their income, and tailored their works to suit the men with the money. To me, that is commercial art. Many 'old masters' and world-famous works can be seen as advertisements - the ceiling of the Sistine chapel as an ad for the Catholic Church, portraits of people advertising their wealth and power, and all those battle scenes portraying the status of nations as international players in the territorial and trade wars, most of which were grounded in global economics.
Upvotes:

That's true Judith, but wouldn't you say what art was then and what art is now are very different things? During the Renaissance the art that they made all served a purpose - it was commissioned with a function, generally a religious function, sometimes votive, commemorative, or to uphold status or establishment. And rather than creative geniuses, artists were artisans, generally paid less than the carpenters who built the structures they painted on. And artisans came under a different categorisation to businessmen or merchants, who belonged to a far superior social level. Today it feels like there are a range of artists to fit many social strata. There are commercial artists for advertising or illustrating or making faux abstract paintings to be mass produced for IKEA or some other store. There are artists who still belong to the 20th century notion of the romantic creative genius struggling with notions of identity and the human condition (which has such an enduring appeal that it is worth revisiting), there are artists who use concept to explore contemporary social challenges in response to globalisation, technology and regenerate thinking, and there are artists who are businessmen, who appear to have consciously and often successfully engaged with market forces. What is challenging is that often these artforms overlap, and also they can all be commoditised. Many artists start out defying and challenging the status quo, including the art establishment itself. The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it. And it is irresistible - think Emin, Banksy etc. It turns their art into commodity which is irresistible to the artist, and irresistible to the buyer - they can be a part of or associated with something that is both powerful and edgy. The idea of making art purely for money is challenging the status quo - challenging our perceptions of the intrinsic value of art - of course it's going to work! Hirst has gone all out - he not only overtly makes art as a commodity - his art boasts that that is what he is doing and he uses (and abuses) artistic motifs that often carry emotional associations for society, thus intrinsically undermines the very artistic values he is purporting to uphold.

About Warhol and business, there was a segment in Burns's Andy Warhol Documentary explaining that Warhol became more 'businesslike' after recovering from the shooting (so early 70s). One of the first moves was to sell off the existing inventory, which had naturally appreciated in value by the early 70s, then undertook commissions for portraits, plus made films for the commercial market (e.g., Warhol's Dracula (1974), which was actually made by Paul Morrissey). Warhol's crew also shifted, out went the drag queens and hustlers, in came those who could work in a more businesslike way (like Morrissey). During this time, Warhol also began Interview Magazine, which of course helped solidify his place among the 'celebs' -- but also the well-known and interesting people. One could also be a tad skeptical and say that the magazine and such increased the value of the Warhol brand .

Throughout history artists have relied on patronage and commissions for their income, and tailored their works to suit the men with the money. To me, that is commercial art. Many 'old masters' and world-famous works can be seen as advertisements - the ceiling of the Sistine chapel as an ad for the Catholic Church, portraits of people advertising their wealth and power, and all those battle scenes portraying the status of nations as international players in the territorial and trade wars, most of which were grounded in global economics.
Upvotes:

That's true Judith, but wouldn't you say what art was then and what art is now are very different things? During the Renaissance the art that they made all served a purpose - it was commissioned with a function, generally a religious function, sometimes votive, commemorative, or to uphold status or establishment. And rather than creative geniuses, artists were artisans, generally paid less than the carpenters who built the structures they painted on. And artisans came under a different categorisation to businessmen or merchants, who belonged to a far superior social level. Today it feels like there are a range of artists to fit many social strata. There are commercial artists for advertising or illustrating or making faux abstract paintings to be mass produced for IKEA or some other store. There are artists who still belong to the 20th century notion of the romantic creative genius struggling with notions of identity and the human condition (which has such an enduring appeal that it is worth revisiting), there are artists who use concept to explore contemporary social challenges in response to globalisation, technology and regenerate thinking, and there are artists who are businessmen, who appear to have consciously and often successfully engaged with market forces. What is challenging is that often these artforms overlap, and also they can all be commoditised. Many artists start out defying and challenging the status quo, including the art establishment itself. The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it. And it is irresistible - think Emin, Banksy etc. It turns their art into commodity which is irresistible to the artist, and irresistible to the buyer - they can be a part of or associated with something that is both powerful and edgy. The idea of making art purely for money is challenging the status quo - challenging our perceptions of the intrinsic value of art - of course it's going to work! Hirst has gone all out - he not only overtly makes art as a commodity - his art boasts that that is what he is doing and he uses (and abuses) artistic motifs that often carry emotional associations for society, thus intrinsically undermines the very artistic values he is purporting to uphold.

About Warhol and business, there was a segment in Burns's Andy Warhol Documentary explaining that Warhol became more 'businesslike' after recovering from the shooting (so early 70s). One of the first moves was to sell off the existing inventory, which had naturally appreciated in value by the early 70s, then undertook commissions for portraits, plus made films for the commercial market (e.g., Warhol's Dracula (1974), which was actually made by Paul Morrissey). Warhol's crew also shifted, out went the drag queens and hustlers, in came those who could work in a more businesslike way (like Morrissey). During this time, Warhol also began Interview Magazine, which of course helped solidify his place among the 'celebs' -- but also the well-known and interesting people. Throughout history artists have relied on patronage and commissions for their income, and tailored their works to suit the men with the money. To me, that is commercial art. Many 'old masters' and world-famous works can be seen as advertisements - the ceiling of the Sistine chapel as an ad for the Catholic Church, portraits of people advertising their wealth and power, and all those battle scenes portraying the status of nations as international players in the territorial and trade wars, most of which were grounded in global economics.
Upvotes:
3
That's true Judith, but wouldn't you say what art was then and what art is now are very different things? During the Renaissance the art that they made all served a purpose - it was commissioned with a function, generally a religious function, sometimes votive, commemorative, or to uphold status or establishment. And rather than creative geniuses, artists were artisans, generally paid less than the carpenters who built the structures they painted on. And artisans came under a different categorisation to businessmen or merchants, who belonged to a far superior social level. Today it feels like there are a range of artists to fit many social strata. There are commercial artists for advertising or illustrating or making faux abstract paintings to be mass produced for IKEA or some other store. There are artists who still belong to the 20th century notion of the romantic creative genius struggling with notions of identity and the human condition (which has such an enduring appeal that it is worth revisiting), there are artists who use concept to explore contemporary social challenges in response to globalisation, technology and regenerate thinking, and there are artists who are businessmen, who appear to have consciously and often successfully engaged with market forces. What is challenging is that often these artforms overlap, and also they can all be commoditised. Many artists start out defying and challenging the status quo, including the art establishment itself. The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it. And it is irresistible - think Emin, Banksy etc. It turns their art into commodity which is irresistible to the artist, and irresistible to the buyer - they can be a part of or associated with something that is both powerful and edgy. The idea of making art purely for money is challenging the status quo - challenging our perceptions of the intrinsic value of art - of course it's going to work! Hirst has gone all out - he not only overtly makes art as a commodity - his art boasts that that is what he is doing and he uses (and abuses) artistic motifs that often carry emotional associations for society, thus intrinsically undermines the very artistic values he is purporting to uphold.

About Warhol and business, there was a segment in Burns's Andy Warhol Documentary explaining that Warhol became more 'businesslike' after recovering from the shooting (so early 70s). One of the first moves was to sell off the existing inventory, which had naturally appreciated in value by the early 70s, then undertook commissions for portraits, plus made films for the commercial market (e.g., Warhol's Dracula (1974), which was actually made by Paul Morrissey). Warhol's crew also shifted, out went the drag queens and hustlers, in came those who could work in a more businesslike way (like Morrissey). During this time, Warhol also began Interview Magazine, which of course helped solidify his place among the 'celebs' -- but also the well-known and interesting people. One could also be a tad skeptical and say that the magazine and such increased the value of the Warhol brand .

Throughout history artists have relied on patronage and commissions for their income, and tailored their works to suit the men with the money. To me, that is commercial art. Many 'old masters' and world-famous works can be seen as advertisements - the ceiling of the Sistine chapel as an ad for the Catholic Church, portraits of people advertising their wealth and power, and all those battle scenes portraying the status of nations as international players in the territorial and trade wars, most of which were grounded in global economics.
Upvotes:
3
That's true Judith, but wouldn't you say what art was then and what art is now are very different things? During the Renaissance the art that they made all served a purpose - it was commissioned with a function, generally a religious function, sometimes votive, commemorative, or to uphold status or establishment. And rather than creative geniuses, artists were artisans, generally paid less than the carpenters who built the structures they painted on. And artisans came under a different categorisation to businessmen or merchants, who belonged to a far superior social level. Today it feels like there are a range of artists to fit many social strata. There are commercial artists for advertising or illustrating or making faux abstract paintings to be mass produced for IKEA or some other store. There are artists who still belong to the 20th century notion of the romantic creative genius struggling with notions of identity and the human condition (which has such an enduring appeal that it is worth revisiting), there are artists who use concept to explore contemporary social challenges in response to globalisation, technology and regenerate thinking, and there are artists who are businessmen, who appear to have consciously and often successfully engaged with market forces. What is challenging is that often these artforms overlap, and also they can all be commoditised. Many artists start out defying and challenging the status quo, including the art establishment itself. The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it. And it is irresistible - think Emin, Banksy etc. It turns their art into commodity which is irresistible to the artist, and irresistible to the buyer - they can be a part of or associated with something that is both powerful and edgy. The idea of making art purely for money is challenging the status quo - challenging our perceptions of the intrinsic value of art - of course it's going to work! Hirst has gone all out - he not only overtly makes art as a commodity - his art boasts that that is what he is doing and he uses (and abuses) artistic motifs that often carry emotional associations for society, thus intrinsically undermines the very artistic values he is purporting to uphold.

About Warhol and business, there was a segment in Burns's Andy Warhol Documentary explaining that Warhol became more 'businesslike' after recovering from the shooting (so early 70s). One of the first moves was to sell off the existing inventory, which had naturally appreciated in value by the early 70s, then undertook commissions for portraits, plus made films for the commercial market (e.g., Warhol's Dracula (1974), which was actually made by Paul Morrissey). Warhol's crew also shifted, out went the drag queens and hustlers, in came those who could work in a more businesslike way (like Morrissey). During this time, Warhol also began Interview Magazine, which of course helped solidify his place among the 'celebs' -- but also the well-known and interesting people. One could also be a tad skeptical and say that the magazine and such increased the value of the Warhol brand .

Throughout history artists have relied on patronage and commissions for their income, and tailored their works to suit the men with the money. To me, that is commercial art. Many 'old masters' and world-famous works can be seen as advertisements - the ceiling of the Sistine chapel as an ad for the Catholic Church, portraits of people advertising their wealth and power, and all those battle scenes portraying the status of nations as international players in the territorial and trade wars, most of which were grounded in global economics.
Upvotes:
3
That's true Judith, but wouldn't you say what art was then and what art is now are very different things? During the Renaissance the art that they made all served a purpose - it was commissioned with a function, generally a religious function, sometimes votive, commemorative, or to uphold status or establishment. And rather than creative geniuses, artists were artisans, generally paid less than the carpenters who built the structures they painted on. And artisans came under a different categorisation to businessmen or merchants, who belonged to a far superior social level. Today it feels like there are a range of artists to fit many social strata. There are commercial artists for advertising or illustrating or making faux abstract paintings to be mass produced for IKEA or some other store. There are artists who still belong to the 20th century notion of the romantic creative genius struggling with notions of identity and the human condition (which has such an enduring appeal that it is worth revisiting), there are artists who use concept to explore contemporary social challenges in response to globalisation, technology and regenerate thinking, and there are artists who are businessmen, who appear to have consciously and often successfully engaged with market forces. What is challenging is that often these artforms overlap, and also they can all be commoditised. Many artists start out defying and challenging the status quo, including the art establishment itself. The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it. And it is irresistible - think Emin, Banksy etc. It turns their art into commodity which is irresistible to the artist, and irresistible to the buyer - they can be a part of or associated with something that is both powerful and edgy. The idea of making art purely for money is challenging the status quo - challenging our perceptions of the intrinsic value of art - of course it's going to work! Hirst has gone all out - he not only overtly makes art as a commodity - his art boasts that that is what he is doing and he uses (and abuses) artistic motifs that often carry emotional associations for society, thus intrinsically undermines the very artistic values he is purporting to uphold.

About Warhol and business, there was a segment in Burns's Andy Warhol Documentary explaining that Warhol became more 'businesslike' after recovering from the shooting (so early 70s). One of the first moves was to sell off the existing inventory, which had naturally appreciated in value by the early 70s, then undertook commissions for portraits, plus made films for the commercial market (e.g., Warhol's Dracula (1974), which was actually made by Paul Morrissey). Warhol's crew also shifted, out went the drag queens and hustlers, in came those who could work in a more businesslike way (like Morrissey). During this time, Warhol also began Interview Magazine, which of course helped solidify his place among the 'celebs' -- but also the well-known and interesting people. One could also be a tad skeptical and say that the magazine and such increased the value of the Warhol brand .

Art is always been business with the exclusion of prehistoric art and other forms of primitive expression (i.e. aboriginal art). What has been changing is the nature of the business. For 5000 years art was a private question between power and artist. Giotto was a rich businessman who sought richer than him people like Mr. Scrovegni to sell his artworks. The resteless and criminal Caravaggio worked for the most important cardinals in Rome. Everything changed in the 1800s. Industry and technology made available for everybody printed images, photos, posters, books and magazines. Art became popular in different way. Some great artist drew the label for Campbell soup, Andy forged it. Pop art already existed before the Pop art, but critics, museum curators and art dealeres didn't care about it. Just to make a point; in what Andy's films are more experimental than 'The Big Combo' (1955) or 'Street Angel' (1928)?

Two days ago, Kirsty commented, 'The art establishment is however the scariest and cleverest of creatures, because, when it sees that it is being successfully challenged it simply morphs itself to absorb and claim what appears to be rejecting it.' This as much a comment about capitalism as we know and are forced to embrace it as it is about art, which is not surprising as art functions within the environment it finds itself, be it to reflect it, offer a commentary on it, or reject it. To me, Warhol's efforts to embrace and reflect commerce directly as the new high religion is, as people have commented, not so very different to the Old Masters taking a wage to reflect the religion of the day. We look back at the Old Masters with a degree of reverence, I suspect, because of the visible quality of their painterly skills. It is easier for us to create a story about how they managed to overcome the difficulties they faced in creating their art than mythologise the craft of an artist like Warhol. Silk-screening doesn't have the same romantic allure as lying on your back for three years to paint a ceiling. (Perhaps its the lying on your back that captivates the imagination.)

I think that Warhol's successful navigation of the commercial and fine art worlds speaks to his knack for irony. In the 1980s, his work satirized how businessmen bought art for the practical purpose of investments, while he embraced the wealth that resulted from a business-oriented economic climate. His appreciation for money may have irritated the art establishment, but his openness about serving his self interests lends to the notion that he was true to himself.

Two quotes by famous visual artists that I think add to the spirit of this thread. 'I believe more and more that to work for the sake of the work is the principle of all great artists: not to be discouraged even though almost starving, and though one feels one has to say farewell to all material comfort.' Van Gogh to his brother Theo in the book My Life and Love Are One 'Well, success is an important thing! It's often been said that an artist ought to work for himself, for the 'love of art,' that he ought to have contempt for success. Untrue! An artist needs success. And not only to live off it, but especially to produce his body of work. Even a rich painter has to have success. Few people understand anything about art, and not everyone is sensitive to painting. Most judge the world of art by success. Why, then,leave success to 'best-selling painters'? Every generation has its own. But where is it written that success must always go to those who cater to the public's taste? For myself, I wanted to prove that you can have success in spite of everyone, without compromise. Do you know what? It's the success I had when I was young that became my wall of protection. The blue period, the rose period, they were screens that shielded me.' Picasso to photographer Brassaï in the book Conversations with Picasso
